author: soispoke
content:
- Anywhere in block means you have no guarantees IL transactions will end up at a specific position relative to the execution payload (unlike top-of-block or end-of-block) 

- The main question we have to answer when thinking about ILs being crowded by preconfs or valuable MEV txns is: Is it better to use ILs as a vehicle to include transactions than just trying to get your transaction in the block via builders, or directly communicating with proposers ("preconfers") using a dedicated lane/mechanism? 

I think with FOCIL and its current properties the answer is it's less practical to use ILs (via committee members) to include valuable transactions or to guarantee preconf commitments will be honored (or that preconfers will be slashed if not). At the end of the day, if you do want guarantees about your transaction being included or being put in a particular position in a block, you do want to rely on the block producer (proposer or builder), he's the one having the last look, and ultimately has more power to decide what goes in or not and where

author: potuz
content:
The middleware enables a centralized server to be contacted by many validators. There are many levels of preconfirmations that different degrees of trust people can act on. Some people will be happy to act on Arbitrum's sequencer's receipt. Others will wait for the transaction to appear on an L2 block, others will wait until the block appears in a batch in L1, and others will wait until this is consumed in L2 upon L1 finality. People are willing to act differently because there's different levels of danger and safety that the transaction will be included and how. 

If I am in a situation in which there are two builders that are making all Ethereum blocks, and I send them a transaction, and they both give me a receipt, I can trust that they will include it in a next block. If they are also the preconfers on which validators are connected and they include it in an IL, I get an onchain receipt, something that was seen by validators. This is the same difference than the receipt from the sequencer (that I hold and no one else saw) vs the L2 block that was seen by everyone and my tx was sequenced.

author: potuz
content: they both can be false: the builder can lie because they already filled the block and won't include my tx, and the sequencer can lie and actually equivocate on L2.

author: potuz
content: the cost of that lie is higher than the cost of just not doing anything after giving me a receipt, and that's what makes a receipt of an IL inclusion more valuable than the receipt from the builder that it will include my tx
